thread.title: Granville home smashes the reserve price by $1.53 million
thread.title_full: Granville home smashes the reserve price by $1.53 million

author: Kirsten Craze
title: Granville home smashes the reserve price by $1.53 million
text:
A keen developer has paid a huge $2.781 million under the hammer for a humble home in Granville — just to knock it down.
The cladded home on 1440sq m, which was described in marketing material by selling agent Tony Eltakchi as being in “very poor condition” sold for a huge $1.531 million over the set reserve.
“It was pretty hard to set a price guide for the property, but in the beginning we were thinking it would go for a bit over $1 million,” he said.
“So many developers were keen on getting it but they were really playing their cards close to their chests,” he said. The 1440sq m site is next door to the Granville RSL Club. Source: Supplied
A crowd of more than 100 people gathered to see 33 William St go under the hammer today. Photo Jeremy Piper Source: News Corp Australia
The dual access block, which sits next door to the Granville RSL Club and it only 250m from Clyde Station, was hotly contested by 20 registered buyers. One of the unsuccessful bidders was vying for the property on behalf of the club.
Auctioneer Rob Trovato of Auction Services said the final result was “crazy” with bidding beginning at $950,000 and then coming think and fast.
“My poor scribe was running out of paper there were that many bids,” he said.
“But the buyer actually came in really late around the $2.72 million mark,” Mr Trovato said.
Zoned R4 for high-density development, Mr Eltakchi of LJ Hooker Granville/Guildford said the vast possibilities for redevelopment fuelled the bidding fire.
“Even at that high price they still could see some cream in it for them. Obviously all these developers see something in it that maybe the rest of us didn’t,” he said.
Mr Trovato added that the sale was an example of “land banking” — a phenomenon that is growing in suburban Sydney.
“These developers just buy and wait for the neighbours to sell so they can build something more substantial,” he said.
“Although that Williams St block is big enough to allow multidensity redevelopment, the 15m frontage doesn’t,” he said.
Auctioneer Rob Trovato taking bids at 33 William Stt, Granville. Photo: Jeremy Piper Source: News Corp Australia
In the same family for more than 40 years, the vendor who wished to remain anonymous said the huge result would change his family’s life.
“It’s an outrageous price,” he said.
“We were worried beforehand that it was going to fall through, but we never expected that price. This changes everything,” he said.
Originally published as Home smashes reserve by $1.53m
